channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Record Debt in the World’s Richest Nations Threatens Global Growth
item.description: The cost of borrowing is already choking crucial public spending in many developing economies. Now it’s raising broader alarms.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Record-high debt in the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan risks slowing growth and destabilizing the global economy.

item.title: Trump Administration Takes Another Stake in Rare Earth Sector
item.description: The administration announced a $1.6 billion deal with USA Rare Earth. The firm also does business with Cantor Fitzgerald, which is run by the sons of President Trump’s commerce secretary.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Liam Kennedy for The New York Times
item.media:description: “This investment ensures our supply chains are resilient and no longer reliant on foreign nations,” Howard Lutnick, the secretary of commerce, said of the deal.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Raise Tariffs on South Korea to 25%
item.description: President Trump threatened to increase tariffs on South Korean exports, including cars, citing the country’s slow ratification of a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Monday said he would raise tariffs on South Korea.

item.title: A Year After DC Plane Crash, Concerns About Airport’s Safety Continue
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration says it has reduced traffic in and out of the airport and designed safer routes. Crash victims’ families want more.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times

item.title: Washington Post Reverses Decision on Olympics Coverage
item.description: The newspaper will send a small team of reporters to cover the Olympics after it informed sports journalists on Friday that the paper would not send a group.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:description: The Olympic rings and the Paralympics Agitos logo in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy.

item.title: Power Outages Could Rise as Freezing Temperatures Persist After Winter Storm
item.description: Electrical grids appeared to have handled the storm over the weekend relatively well, but energy experts said the risk of more outages remained.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most power outages resulted from snow piling up on electrical equipment and ice dangling from trees and power lines.

item.title: Public Media Holds Its Apocalypse at Bay, for Now
item.description: Though Congress cut $500 million from NPR and PBS stations, vanishingly few have closed their doors. Angst about their long-term future remains.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Lemia Monet Bodden for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recording studio at the KQED radio station in San Francisco.

item.title: New Videos of the Beckham Feud Are Fake. Nobody Seems to Care.
item.description: A.I.-generated content of Victoria Beckham has spread as wedding drama has engulfed the celebrity clan and the public has clamored for receipts (even fabricated ones).
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: Brooklyn Beckham, center, the eldest son of David Beckham, left, and Victoria Beckham, right, openly criticized his famous parents last week.

item.title: Business Leaders Face a Test in Minneapolis
item.description: Some companies have begun to respond to the fatal shooting of Alex Jeffrey Pretti and the immigration crackdown. But others have stayed silent.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Vivienne Walt
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The fatal shooting of Alex Jeffrey Pretti by federal agents has made the federal immigration campaign in Minneapolis a powder keg that business leaders are now confronting.

item.title: Gold Soars Beyond $5,000 as Global Tensions Grow
item.description: The price of gold surged as investors sought shelter from geopolitical uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Schmidt and Kailyn Rhone
item.media:description: Gold has become a safe haven for investors worried about global uncertainty.

item.title: Thousands of Flights Canceled Monday After Snowstorm
item.description: Delays and cancellations persisted a day after more than 11,000 flights were canceled. Airports in the Northeastern U.S. were hit the hardest.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi, Christine Chung, Gabe Castro-Root and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Passengers at LaGuardia Airport dealt with delays and cancellations from the storm on Sunday.

item.title: Elon Musk’s X Faces EU Inquiry Over Sexualized AI Images Generated by Grok
item.description: Regulators said the company’s lack of controls had led to the widespread use of deepfakes created with the chatbot Grok.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:description: The investigation is likely to escalate a confrontation between Europe and the United States over the regulation of online content.

item.title: Voters See a Middle-Class Lifestyle as Drifting Out of Reach, Poll Finds
item.description: Concerns about the affordability of education, housing, health care, having a family and retirement are driving economic anxieties, a New York Times/Siena poll found.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer, Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker

item.title: Goodwill Thrives as Americans Stretch Their Dollars
item.description: Consumers are still spending, but they’re looking for ways to stretch their dollars as far as possible.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin and Sophia June
item.media:credit: DeSean McClinton-Holland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Part of the appeal for Goodwill shoppers is the treasure hunt of searching the racks for hidden gems.

item.title: Trump Hobbled the I.R.S. This C.E.O. Now Has to Make It Work.
item.description: Frank Bisignano is the first chief executive of the I.R.S., where there’s hope he will end a chaotic stretch at the agency. The tax filing season, which started Monday, is his first test.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:description: This year’s tax filing season could be an even more formidable challenge than usual for the Internal Revenue Service and Frank Bisignano, its chief executive.

item.title: How Bad Are A.I. Delusions? We Asked People Treating Them.
item.description: Dozens of doctors and therapists said chatbots had led their patients to psychosis, isolation and unhealthy habits.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Valentino-DeVries and Kashmir Hill
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julia Sheffield, a psychologist at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville, is navigating how to treat problems caused or exacerbated by A.I. chatbots.

item.title: As Europe’s Reliance on U.S. Natural Gas Grows, So Does Trump’s Leverage
item.description: Tension over Greenland has prompted worries that the Trump administration could turn the U.S. oil and gas industry into a way to pressure Europe.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: A tanker waits to dock at a liquefied natural gas plant in Hammerfest, Norway, in 2024.

item.title: Most Fox News Reporting on Minneapolis Shooting Supports Official Version
item.description: Fox anchors were laser focused on promoting the Trump administration’s narrative that the slain protester, Alex Pretti, had brought the violence upon himself.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A handmade sign memorializes Alex Pretti, who was shot and killed by immigration agents on Saturday in Minneapolis.

item.title: CEOs of Target and Minnesota’s Biggest Companies Call for ‘De-Escalation’ After Shooting
item.description: The letter from chief executives at some of the state’s most recognizable companies like Target and Cargill stops short of condemning the recent killings by federal immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Federal immigration agents outside a Target in St. Paul, Minn., on Sunday.

item.title: Trump Pushes A.I. Data Centers, but the G.O.P. Is Cool to One in Alabama
item.description: Residents also oppose a data center the size of 18 Walmarts that is set to be built in pristine woodland outside Bessemer, Ala. “All this will be gone,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper and Vincent Alban

item.title: High January Is the New Dry January. Sales of THC Drinks Are Booming.
item.description: Sales of beverages containing hemp-derived THC are rising as consumers look for the buzz without the booze. But a new federal law could push them off shelves.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Sara Stathas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nonalcoholic THC-infused beverages such as Drinkin’ Buds have become a popular alternative for people giving up alcohol for the month of January.

item.title: Hard Times in the Mississippi Delta as Farmers Consider Letting Crops Rot
item.description: Prices for nearly every major U.S. crop are below what it costs to grow them. But a drop in rice prices means another blow to farmers in Mississippi’s agricultural belt.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.media:credit: Imani Khayyam for The New York Times
item.media:description: “What am I supposed to do with 2.2 million pounds of rice?” asked Jack Westerfield, who is among the farmers across the Mississippi Delta who cannot sell their rice.

item.title: Washington Post Tears Up Plans to Cover Winter Olympics
item.description: The abrupt change in direction came just weeks before the Olympic Games are set to begin in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin and Erik Wemple
item.media:description: The Olympic Rings and the Paralympics Agitos in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy, where some of the events in the Winter Olympics will be held next month.

item.title: Interest in Law School Is Surging. A.I. Makes the Payoff Less Certain.
item.description: The number of applicants has risen more than 40 percent over the last two years, despite new limits on student loans and uncertainty over how artificial intelligence will affect legal work.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Olson
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: London Cooper, an undergraduate student in her final year at Dillard University, plans to pursue a law degree despite the high cost.

item.title: Why the Power May Not Go Out Until After the Storm Has Passed
item.description: The steady accumulation of snow and freezing rain and a rise in demand for electricity can cause problems long after the sky clears, energy experts said.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Karen Weise
item.media:description: As snow and ice accumulate on tree branches and power lines, it can cause them to snap and damage electrical equipment.

item.title: Will Leaving My Terrible Job Make Me Look Flaky?
item.description: And, picking up the slack for a colleague with long Covid.
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Automakers’ Foreign Troubles Now Extend to Canada
item.description: U.S. trade policy has devastated the Canadian auto industry and pushed the country to reach an agreement that will make it easier for Chinese companies to sell cars there.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Canada could serve as an important test market for Chinese automakers, like Geely, which is producing vehicles at a plant in Hangzhou, China.

item.title: Travel Math: When Flying Costs as Much as the Train, Who Wins?
item.description: Amtrak says dynamic pricing has helped strengthen its finances, but travelers often grumble at the cost, especially for last-minute travel. Still, the train has a secret weapon: avoiding the airport.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:description: The rail service adjusted its approach as ridership began to pick up as pandemic-era restrictions loosened.

item.title: Tremors in Japan Prompt Treasury to Weigh Currency Intervention
item.description: New York Fed inquiries about the cost of exchanging yen for dollars signaled to traders on Friday that the U.S. government might make a large purchase of the Japanese currency.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison, Alan Rappeport and Colby Smith
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:description: The possibility of a large-scale purchase of yen at some point by the U.S. Treasury lifted the currency’s value 1.6 percent against the dollar on Friday.

item.title: S.E.C. Drops Case Against Cryptocurrency Firm Founded by Winklevoss Twins
item.description: The agency says that victims of an investment offering involving Gemini Trust got their money back, though after a regulatory action brought by the New York attorney general.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess and Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss at a digital assets summit at the White House last March.

item.title: Saudi Arabia-Backed LIV Golf to Hold Tournament at the Trumps’ New Jersey Resort
item.description: It will be the latest in at least half a dozen events that the breakaway league has held at Trump Organization resorts in the past four years.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Besides events at Bedminster, the golf league has held annual tournaments at the Trump Doral resort in Miami.

item.title: TikTok Updates Its Terms and Conditions in the U.S.
item.description: The changes came after the app’s Chinese parent company spun out an American entity to run TikTok in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:description: The new version of TikTok’s privacy policy states that, if users enable location services, the company can collect approximate or precise location information.

item.title: For His Next Act, Darren Walker Is Heading to Hollywood
item.description: Anonymous Content, a production company whose top investor is Laurene Powell Jobs’s Emerson Collective, has named Darren Walker as president and chief executive.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Nate Langston Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Storytelling shapes culture, informs how we see ourselves and how we see the humanity in others,” Darren Walker said of his move to Anonymous Content.

item.title: Airlines Cancel Hundreds of Flights In Anticipation of Powerful Winter Storm
item.description: Airlines are canceling hundreds of flights over the weekend in anticipation of frigid weather and ice and snow across much of the country.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York City last month. A major winter storm that is forecast to sweep across the country in the coming days could cause cancellations and delays that linger into next week.

item.title: Trump Wants U.S. Investment in Venezuela, but Sanctions Still Complicate It
item.description: With tight business restrictions still in place, companies may find it challenging to even assess what opportunities exist for them in the South American nation.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Krolik and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil tanker in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021. U.S. economic sanctions on individual Venezuelan officials began under President Barack Obama and were expanded by President Trump.

item.title: For Greenland Tourism, Trump’s Interest Creates Uncertainty
item.description: Bookings to the island increased last year, and there are plans for two new airports. Threats from President Trump may change that.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Abend
item.media:description: Tourism in Greenland, a semiautonomous territory of the Kingdom of Denmark, has been rising steadily for years. Now some in the tourism industry are worried that recent geopolitical attention will have a negative impact.

item.title: Low Rates Sound Great. But a Trump Fed Could Cause a Painful ‘Sugar High.’
item.description: Dropping rates more than conditions warrant would stimulate the economy in the short term but could lead to trouble, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer

item.title: What to Know About New Rules for 401(k) ‘Catch-Up’ Contributions in 2026
item.description: Older high-income workers who make contributions beyond the standard amount will have to put that extra money into a Roth 401(k). That may lower their take-home pay.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: The Message Behind Trump’s Lawsuit Against JPMorgan
item.description: The president’s legal efforts against the Wall Street giant and Jamie Dimon, its chief executive, have put Corporate America on edge.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase has sought to walk a fine line in dealing with President Trump.

item.title: Storm Poses Big Threats to Power Grids Across U.S.
item.description: Managers of electric grids say freezing temperatures and ice and snow could lead to power outages in many places, potentially leaving millions in the dark.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Joel Bissell/Kalamazoo Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Heavy snow and freezing rain can weigh down tree branches and power lines, causing equipment failures that can often cripple power systems.

item.title: Five Ways People Are Using Claude Code
item.description: Claude Code generates computer code when people type prompts, so those with no coding experience can create their own programs and apps.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, chief executive of Anthropic, at the Code With Claude developer conference in San Francisco last year.

item.title: After TikTok Deal, Chinese Firms Search for a New Global Path
item.description: Chinese firms must contend with geopolitical tensions and mistrust to do business in the United States. Some are choosing to avoid the U.S. altogether.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin
item.media:description: The short-video platform TikTok, owned by ByteDance, has become a geopolitical football in relations between the United States and China.

item.title: Will I Have to Download a New TikTok App? And Other Big Questions About The Deal.
item.description: The popular short form video app has a new corporate structure in the United States, which could result in some changes for the 200 million Americans who use TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: It is unclear how much, if anything, will change for TikTok’s 200 million American users.

item.title: Here’s Who Just Bought TikTok
item.description: Several big companies and investment firms are part of the new American TikTok. Many have ties to one another and President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times

item.title: Big Insurers Try to Shift Blame for High Health Costs to Hospitals and Drug Makers
item.description: At two congressional hearings, lawmakers slammed executives of major companies, saying they were failing to rein in the cost of medical care for consumers.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn
item.media:description: Stephen Hemsley, chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, left, defended insurers’ practices, along with other companies’ executives, during congressional hearings on Thursday.

item.title: New U.S. Rule Aims to Speed Up Mining of the Seafloor
item.description: The Metals Company, a prominent seabed-mining company, applauded the change and filed a new application more than doubling the area it hopes to mine.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ship chartered by the Metals Company to explore the viability of mining the seabed in the Pacific in 2021.

item.title: Trump Could Begin Flying on Plane Donated by Qatar by Summer
item.description: It remains unclear whether the aircraft would get the full Air Force One security upgrades, which industry experts said could take up to two years to complete.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Trump had to swap to a smaller plane used as Air Force One on Tuesday night, as he was heading to Switzerland, after an electrical issue with the larger aircraft.

item.title: Trump Sues JPMorgan, Saying the Bank Closed His Accounts for Political Reasons
item.description: The lawsuit, citing “political discrimination,” said the banking giant told President Trump shortly after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol that it would close his accounts.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:description: The lawsuit says Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan’s chief executive, directed the bank to put Mr. Trump and some of his businesses on a “blacklist.”

item.title: Here’s What to Know if You Plan to Travel During the Winter Storm
item.description: Airlines have canceled more than 13,000 flights, as a powerful storm brings ice, sleet and major snowfall to the Midwest, South and Northeast.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung and Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:description: Ronald Reagan National Airport, near Washington, has seen disruptions this weekend and airlines canceled all flights on Sunday.

item.title: Why Trump’s Reversal on Greenland Still Leaves Europe on Edge
item.description: Andrew Ross Sorkin, editor at large of DealBook, describes how leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos remain on edge after President Trump, for now, backed down from threats of using tariffs or military force to gain Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Rebecca Suner, Coleman Lowndes, Laura Salaberry and Nikolay Nikolov
